jsonb_agg.case_summary:
On February 15, 2024, Plaintiff Alma Socorro Cristobal Avendaño was traveling northbound in the right lane on Interstate 65 in Louisville, Kentucky, when she was involved in a sideswipe collision with a commercial truck operated by Roy Hamilton and owned by Crete Carrier Corporation. According to the police report, Ms. Cristobal was struck when Hamilton merged into her lane, forcing her into the guardrail. She sustained a fractured left clavicle, chest pain, and shoulder pain, requiring emergency treatment at UofL Health - Mary & Elizabeth Hospital via EMS transport.

Ms. Cristobal has received extensive medical treatment including: emergency care at UofL hospitals, imaging at Heartland Imaging confirming the clavicular fracture, ongoing treatment at Aptiva Health (4/2/24-9/18/24), and chiropractic care at Starlite Chiropractic. Total medical expenses exceed $24,000, with approximately $9,540 paid through PIP benefits (Kentucky Farm Bureau claim #4943385, adjuster Lauren Baker) which are now exhausted.

A lawsuit was filed in Jefferson County Circuit Court (24-CI-004728) with active litigation ongoing. Defense counsel Aletha Thomas (Kopka Pinkus Dolin) represents Crete Carrier Corporation, which initially denied liability through their BI coverage (claim #2024346878, adjuster Brenna Rine) on 4/4/24. 

Discovery has been contentious, with multiple rounds of supplemental requests served regarding the commercial vehicle's Electronic Data Recorder (EDR) information. Defendant Hamilton claimed during deposition that no collision occurred while he was driving, alleging any damage happened later while parked - a position we dispute based on physical evidence. Defense counsel has been non-responsive to supplemental discovery requests about EDR data, leading to multiple follow-up communications from April through July 2025. A motion to compel discovery has been drafted and is ready for filing if defense responses are not received promptly.
jsonb_agg.current_status: Depositions completed. Motion to compel supplemental discovery regarding EDR information drafted and ready to file. Awaiting defense counsel's responses to supplemental discovery requests served in April 2025 - multiple follow-ups sent with no response. PIP benefits exhausted. BI carrier denied liability but case proceeding in litigation. Next action: File motion to compel if no response received from defense counsel soon.

jsonb_agg.case_summary:
On January 3, 2021, Plaintiff Anella Noble was a passenger in a vehicle on Westhall Avenue at Wilderness Road in Louisville, Kentucky, when they were struck from behind by a vehicle operated by an individual who fled the scene on foot immediately after the collision. Client was very pregnant at the time and was transported to Baptist Health Louisville by Louisville Metro EMS.

The driver of the striking vehicle was not present when officers arrived. The registered owner, Virginia Sewell, later reported the vehicle as stolen approximately 20 minutes after the collision. The police noted that the push-to-start vehicle showed no signs of ignition damage. Officers questioned Sewell about the keys, and she initially stated she only had one set, later revising her statement to say a spare key existed but had not been located. In her deposition, Sewell testified she did not know who had taken her vehicle but admitted speaking with her boyfriend before filing the theft report.

PARTIES: Case filed against Virginia Sewell and Estate of DeShawn Ford (originally her boyfriend who was driving - now deceased). 

LITIGATION STATUS: Third Amended Complaint filed 9/12/2023. Depositions completed of Anella Noble (6/21/2022) and Virginia Sewell (3/23/2023). State Farm dismissed from case (12/4/2023).

MEDICAL TREATMENT: Client treated by Louisville Metro EMS, Baptist Health Louisville, Louisville Emergency Medical Associates, OB Hospitalist Group, The Injury Centers, Bluegrass Bone & Joint, and Etown Chiropractic Center. Total medical bills: $10,407.39.

INSURANCE: Three insurance companies involved: Aetna Life (Medicaid), Anthem Medicaid Health Plans (PHI), and Safeco Insurance (KAC). All coverage confirmed.

DEFENSE COUNSEL: Renee Hoskins (Smith & Hoskins) for Virginia Sewell; David Klapheke (Dinsmore) for Estate of DeShawn Ford.

FILE ORGANIZATION: Comprehensive file organization completed 11/30/2025 using 8-bucket system with content-based naming. 395+ files inventoried, 8 files successfully reorganized into proper structure. Files now properly categorized and easily retrievable.

Still pending: discussion with Rob Mattingly about police officer contact (due 9/3/2025). EMS bills and records sent to Safeco adjuster 8/14/2024 for payment. Need to follow up on medical record requests for all providers and finalize discovery before proceeding to trial preparation. File organization completed 11/30/2025 - case files now organized in 8-bucket structure with standardized naming.

jsonb_agg.case_summary:
On April 1, 2023, Greg Neltner and his daughter, Cecelia Neltner, were involved in a motor
vehicle collision on Burlington Pike (KY-18) in Florence, Kentucky. According to the police
report, the defendant, Trinity Cohara, attempted to cross three lanes of traffic from the far-right
eastbound lane in order to turn left onto the northbound I-75 on-ramp. In doing so, she turned
directly in front of Mr. Neltner’s vehicle, which was traveling straight in the left eastbound lane.
Mr. Neltner had no time to react and struck Ms. Cohara’s vehicle. The police narrative confirms
that the defendant failed to yield and crossed lanes improperly, causing the crash. The defendant
continued onto the ramp and stopped partway down.
Cecelia sustained minor burn-like injuries, believed to be from airbag deployment, which
caused redness, blistering, and rash-like symptoms. She was prescribed topical treatment but has
since recovered, and there is no indication of ongoing issues or permanent injury.
jsonb_agg.current_status: The top offer extended was $7,500 for Greg and $1,000 for Cecelia, which were both rejected. Defense counsel appears unlikely to increase these figures significantly without further records substantiating Greg’s ongoing treatment or a more detailed breakdown of his claimed lost income and limitations.

jsonb_agg.case_summary:
On April 18, 2023, client was involved in a collision at the intersection of West Main
Street and South 22nd Street in Louisville, Kentucky. According to the Louisville Metro Police
Collision Report, Plaintiff was traveling southbound on 22nd Street and reported having a green
light when proceeding through the intersection. The other driver, traveling westbound on Market
Street, stated that he had a red light but proceeded into the intersection regardless. The two
vehicles collided, pushing Plaintiff’s vehicle into a nearby car lot where it struck a parked
vehicle.
There were no witnesses or traffic cameras capturing the incident, and the investigating
officer was unable to make a determination of fault. Body-worn camera footage from the scene is
unfavorable to Plaintiff’s presentation. Settlement discussions are being approached on a 50/50

fault allocation basis.
